Central Bank of Sri Lanka P.O.Box590 Colombo.
CENTRAL BANK'S RATE OF INTEREST ON ADVANCES
The attention of commercial banks is invited to Circular No. 1452 of December 30, 1985.
With effect from June 15, 1989, paragraph 1 of the above-mentioned Circular is amended to read as follows:

"The rate of interest on advances by the Central Bank to commercial banks secured by the pledge of (a) government and government guaranteed securities and, (b) usance promissory notes relating to commercial and production loans will be 14 per centum per annum."
Circular No. 1837 of August 07,1987 is hereby withdrawn.
N. A. Dharmabandu H. N. S. Karunatilake Chief Accountant Governor.
Central Bank of Sri Lanka P.O.Box590 -Colombo 1.

Commercial banks are hereby informed that, with immediate effect and until further notice, the total amount of their advances granted and outstanding to the private sector should not exceed the level of such advances as at May 31,1989.
2. For the purpose of this notification:
(a) the term'advances'means the following rupee assets:
(i) Loans; (ii) Overdrafts; (iii) Import bills financed; and (iv) Local bills financed
and (b) the term 'private sector' includes government corporations and statutory bodies, but does not include

(i) the Development Finance Corporation of Ceylon; (ii) me National Development Bank of Sri Lanka; (iii) the National Savings Bank; (iv) the State Mortgage and Investment Bank; and (v) the Co-operative Wholesale Establishment.
3. Advances granted for the following purposes are exempted from the ceiling stipulated in paragraph (1) above:
(i) Agriculture (including marketing and cultivation loans); (ii) Exports (Export bill financing and pre-shipment credit); and (iii) Industry
4. (a) Margin requirements against Letters of Credit

Letters of Credit should not be opened by commercial banks for the importation of goods mentioned in Schedule 'A' attached, unless such credits are covered by a 100 per cent margin deposited in cash with the credit opening bank at the time such credits are opened.

In the case of existing Letters of Credit covering the importation of goods mentioned in Schedule 'A', no increase in the value of such Letters of Credit should be permitted by banks, except on the terms prescribed in the above • paragraph.
(b) Limitations on Advances by Commercial Banks
N. A. Dharmanandu H. N. S. Karunatilake Chief Accountant Governor

The value of Letters of Credit opened on or before May 31,1989, but against which monies had not been advanced, would be exempted until their expiry from the total amount of advances granted and outstanding of food and foodstuffs, raw materials for agriculture, exports and industry, drugs and pharmaceuticals, capital goods and parts thereof.
The arrangement under 4(a) and (b) above will be in force until November IS, 1989.
5. Inter-bank transactions in the call money market are not subject to any restrictions by the Central Bank.
6. Orculars No. 1095 of March 23,1984 (as amended by Circular No. 1102 of April 06, 1984), No. 1117 of May 16,1984 and No. 1489of February 21,1986 are hereby withdrawn.
All household gas, electrical and mechanical appliances
All ceramic and porcelain ware including sanitary ware
Alcoholic beverages, including beer, ale, stout, port and other fermented cereal beverages
Glassware and tumblers excluding sheet glass
Lamps and lighting fittings excluding flourescent fittings
Motor cars, motor cycles and station wagons
Perfumery, cosmetics, soaps and cleansing and polishing preparations
Photographic and cinematographic supplies and cinematographic apparatus and appliances
Radio, television and audio visual equipment
Wall and floor coverings, carpets and tapestries
Central Bank of Sri Lanka P.O.Box590 Colombo
The attention of commercial banks is invited to paragraph 4(a) and 4(b) of Circular No: 2311 of June 15,1989, with regard to
(a) Margin Requirements Against Letters of Credit and

(b) Limitations on Advances by Commercial Banks, respectively. Commercial banks are hereby informed that these arrangements which were to be withdrawn on November 15, 1989 will now continue to be in force until further notice.
